October 18,1987: Fiction
PRESUMED INNOCENT, by Scott Turow.  (Farrar, Straus & Giroux, $18.95.) A
brutal murder creates a crisis among a big city's politicians and  lawyers.
HEAVEN AND HELL, by John Jakes. (Harcourt Brace Jovanovich, $19.95.) A tale
of two families, the Mains of South Carolina and the Hazards of  Pennsylvania, in
the aftermath of the Civil War.
PATRIOT GAMES, by Tom Clancy. (Putnam, $19.95.) The C.I.A.'s Jack Ryan
battles terrorists in England, Ireland and America.
LEAVING HOME, by Garrison Keillor. (Viking, $18.95.) A collection of Lake
Wobegon monologues, from the radio program "A Prairie Home Companion."
BELOVED, by Toni Morrison. (Knopf, $18.95.) Memories of her past haunt an
escaped slave in post-Civil War Ohio.
SARUM, by Edward Rutherfurd. (Crown, $19.95.) Ten thousand years of English
history, seen through the experiences of five families.
LEGACY, by James A. Michener. (Random House, $16.95.) The ordeal of a
military officer, charged with high crimes, whose family heritage covers 200 years
of constitutional history.
HOT FLASHES, by Barbara Raskin. (St. Martin's, $18.95.) At a friend's funeral,
three women who had it made in the 60's reflect on their past and future.
MISERY, by Stephen King. (Viking, $18.95.) Injured and drugged, an author is
held captive by a psychotic fan.
FREEDOM, by William Safire. (Doubleday, $24.95.) The early years of the Civil
War and Lincoln's developing commitment to emancipation.
THE NEW BREED, by W. E. B. Griffin. (Putnam, $16.95.) American military men
involved in a rebellion in Congo during the 1960's.
THE FIVE BELLS AND BLADEBONE, by Martha Grimes. (Little, Brown, $15.95.)
Scotland Yard's Superintendent Jury and his cronies at a London pub investigate
two deaths.
A SOUTHERN FAMILY, by Gail Godwin.  (Morrow, $18.95.) The effect of a violent
death on the Quicks, an eccentric North Carolina clan.
THE PRINCE OF TIDES, by Pat Conroy.  (Houghton Mifflin, $19.95.) Complex
family relationships in South Carolina and New York City.
WEEP NO MORE, MY LADY, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.)
Love and murder at a swank California health spa.
October 18, 1987
Non-Fiction
VEIL, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $21.95.) The inside story of William
Casey's years at the helm of the C.I.A., 1981 to 1987.
SPYCATCHER, by Peter Wright with Paul Greengrass. (Viking, $19.95.) The
autobiography of a former senior member of the British secret service.
TIME FLIES, by Bill Cosby. (Dolphin/Doubleday, $15.95.) Counting his blessings
and his losses, the television star muses on life at 50.
MAN OF THE HOUSE: The Life and Political Memoirs of Speaker Tip O'Neill, with
William Novak. (Random House, $19.95.) The former Speaker of the House tells
his story.
FAMILY: The Ties That Bind . . . and Gag! by Erma Bombeck. (McGraw-Hill,
$15.95.) Anecdotes about a reunion of the humorist's grown children.
THE CLOSING OF THE AMERICAN MIND, by Allan Bloom. (Simon & Schuster,
$18.95.) A critique of liberal arts education during the past 25 years.
IT'S ALL IN THE PLAYING, by Shirley MacLaine. (Bantam, $18.95.) Behind the
scenes during the filming of the television series "Out on a Limb."
THE GREAT DEPRESSION OF 1990, by Ravi Batra. (Simon & Schuster, $17.95.)
An economist's dire predictions about the coming decade.
THE MAKING OF "THE AFRICAN QUEEN," by Katharine Hepburn. (Knopf,
$15.95.) The actress's experiences with Humphrey Bogart, Lauren Bacall and
John Huston while filming the classic movie.
STRAIGHT ON TILL MORNING, by Mary S. Lovell. (St. Martin's, $16.95.) The life
of Beryl Markham, pioneer aviator and author of "West With the Night."
LOVE, MEDICINE & MIRACLES, by Bernie S. Siegel. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) A
surgeon stresses the importance of the patient's mind and emotions.
CULTURAL LITERACY, by E. D. Hirsch Jr. (Houghton Mifflin, $16.95.) The
information -- geography, history, literature, politics -- that you need to read with.
CRYSTAL WOMAN, by Lynn V. Andrews.  (Warner, $16.95.) The author, on a
quest for inner Knowledge, travels to the heart of Australia.
AN AMERICAN CHILDHOOD, by Annie Dillard. (Harper & Row, $17.95.) An
introspective account of the author's youth, set mainly in Pittsburgh.
THE RENEWAL FACTOR, by Robert H. Waterman Jr. (Bantam, $19.95.) The co-
author of "In Search of Excellence" discusses the importance of innovation in
American business.
